text: We moved down to Third and Wharton. We had gotten moved but it was like – you remember I told you my father drank, but it was still day, and after he had gotten in and put the furniture where it was supposed to go, my mother left, to go to market to get some food to bring into the house.
keypoint: Family moves in; parents leave on separate errands

text: And my father went to take the horses – take the team of horses back. But he didn't come home. He – stopped somewhere on – I dunno, but he – how he – why he wasn't in the house. And of course I was left there with the kids.
keypoint: Father never returns, narrator left watching younger kids

text: Well no sooner did my mother get out of the house – my father went first – then – oh it was such an awful crash came through the window. And I – and I looked and it was a big stone. And then of course they – they – well they stoned the house. And I had sense enough to get the kids into the stairway so that they wouldn't get hurt by flyin' glass.
keypoint: Stones crash through windows; children hustled to safety

text: And I said to them, “Now you stay there. Don't move 'cause nothing will reach you here. And I'm gonna go and see if I can find mom” – (We call our mother mom.)
keypoint: Narrator reassures kids and sets out to find mother

text: And they were crying and carryin' on. I was scared to death, I really was frightened out of my wits.
keypoint: Children sob; narrator panics yet stays protective

text: And I didn't know what to do, but I remember saying a prayer as I went out the front door because I didn't know what was gonna hit me when I went out that door.
keypoint: She prays for courage before stepping outside

text: And I ran – I was ten years old at the time this happened – I ran to Fourth street, because I knew my mother wa-
keypoint: Ten-year-old runs toward Fourth Street market

text: They had push carts in those days, on Fourth street. And it was a Jewish neighborhood and they – they stayed open until – until all hours.
keypoint: Describes pushcart-lined Jewish shopping street

text: Because they would, you know, however much money they could get they wanted. So uh that's where she was going to do her shopping.
keypoint: Explains why mother shops there late

text: And I finally found my mother. I did find her.
keypoint: Narrator finally locates her mother

text: And while I was trying to tell her what had happened a policeman went by. And my voice was such that you could hardly make out what I was saying. I was so nervous and – and – my voice was shaking so,
keypoint: Tries to explain, voice trembling with fear

text: and he wanted to find out what ha- what was wrong with me. And then when he understood what the situation was he turned to my mother and says, “This is a bad neighborhood. It's Irish.”
keypoint: Policeman calls area bad, mainly Irish

text: And he said, “They're known to do things like that, Better move out of there.” My mother said, “I just moved in, how am I gonna move out?” He says, “I dunno.”
keypoint: Officer advises moving; mother challenges his duty

text: He says, “But they don't want any black people in there.” An' he didn't say black 'cause they didn't use black then. But “they don't want anybody in there.” So uh, she said, “Well you're the law.
keypoint: Bias revealed; mother insists on police protection

text: You're supposed to protect us.” He says, “I can't do anything with it.” He was Irish himself. “I can't do anything about it.”
keypoint: Irish officer refuses help despite responsibility

text: So my mother said um, “Where is the uh precinct you work from?” And he told her. I forgot now. I was right there with her
keypoint: Mother asks precinct details; narrator observes

text: but I've forgotten where he told her. So uh she said, “Well if you can't do anything to help me, I'll go see who – if I can't find someone else to help me.” Well in those days black people were so cowed by circumstances an' uniforms and white people, you know, they uh many times didn't assert themselves. But thankfully my mother was not one of those kind.
keypoint: Mother vows to seek other aid, shows determination

text: And she – well I always thought of her as an educated person which she was because she was the only one I knew who had completed high school. She went to Lackawanna high school. And this was – let me see what year was this happening – well it must have been nineteen twenty-five, so you can see what – what the times were.
keypoint: Narrator praises mother’s education and resolve

text: And we went – she took me, and we went to the police station. And they also had police wagons with horses attached to them. Believe it or not in those days. So my mother said, to the captain, “What are you going to do about it?”
keypoint: At station, mother demands action from captain

text: And he says, “Well lady there's nothing we can do about it.” And she says, “You mean to tell me that I have to live under those circumstances and there's nothing that you can do about it?”
keypoint: Captain claims nothing can be done

text: She says – he says, “Well uh the only thing I can tell you to do is to move.” He says, “Because” – he said to me, “Did you see anyone?” And I said, “No.”
keypoint: Police suggest moving; girl never saw attackers

text: He says, “Well how can – how can you” – to my mother – “how can you do anything if you don't know who – who to put the blame on?” An' he says, “I'm sure there was more than one person.”
keypoint: Captain cites lack of suspects, likely group

text: So my mother said, “Well I don't know what I'm going to do.” She says, “But one thing I know I'm not going to do is move. Because I have no money to move with.” They took all we had to, to pay the rent. In that house you had to pay in advance.
keypoint: Mother refuses to move, rent already prepaid

text: And she said, “If they didn't want me there they should not have rented the house to me. Now the real estate agent should be accountable.”
keypoint: Says realtor should be held accountable

text: So anyhow, she said to him, “Well I know one thing you can do.” And he says, “What's that?” She says, “You can take me home.” He said, “Take you home?”
keypoint: Mother requests police escort back home

text: She said, “Yes in the police patrol.” So – I guess they figured “Let's get this lady out of here because she's talking loud and long.” And they had never come up with anybody like that.
keypoint: Officers comply, unsettled by her assertiveness

text: So they put us in the police patrol and they took us home.
keypoint: Family rides home in horse-drawn patrol wagon

text: We weren't far from – from where it was – maybe Fifth street – from where we had moved. And – course with the horses and the police patrol, and the clang – they had a bell that clanged. Clang clang clang –
keypoint: Clanging patrol approaches their new street

text: you know they told you about the trolley that went “Clang.” Well this police patrol that bell they had, it went “Clang clang clang.”
keypoint: Bell’s sound compared to trolley’s clang

text: And um all the neighbors came running out to see what was happening. And of course they saw the man came around the back – I can see it right now – from where he was sitting up front there where the horses came around,
keypoint: Neighbors gather as patrol door swings open

text: and opened the door in the back. And they had a long door in the back where you had to come down steps to get out the back of the – of this police patrol.
keypoint: Back steps lower for family to exit wagon

text: Well we got out of that police patrol – Before the patrol ever left my mother turned and faced all those people that were standing around, and she says, “Why you're doing this to me I don't know.”
keypoint: Mother confronts crowd before patrol departs

text: She says, “I know that I am different from you, color wise, but in every other respect I'm just the same as you are, and all I'm trying to do is provide a home for my family.”
keypoint: Asserts shared humanity and need for home

text: She told them that they had rented the house, she told them how much money she had paid, she had told them that was all the money she had.
keypoint: Reveals rent payment and lack of funds

text: And they had paid that rent for a month. She knew she was going to be there for the month. She did not know beyond the month.
keypoint: Committed to stay at least one month

text: Whether they'd have enough money to pay it for the next month. But she knew they were going to be there for the month.
keypoint: Unsure about affording following month

text: She said, “It is winter time and it is cold. And I cannot afford to be buying windows.” “Now” she said, “Whoever threw the stones I don't know. But you can all see what has happened.
keypoint: Winter, broken windows, unknown stone-throwers

text: And now I'm telling you that we're going to be here for a month. So you might just as well make up your mind to that. If you don't want me here then you people get together and give me enough money to move somewhere else, because I do not have it.”
keypoint: Challenges neighbors: accept us or fund move

text: Well of course you know they didn't do that. They probably didn't have any money either.
keypoint: Neighbors provide no money to relocate

text: So in the meantime – not in the meantime but during, during the period of time that we were there, my father became sick. And the neighbors were as nice as anybody could ever have been. When there was trouble they responded just like anyone else.
keypoint: Father later ill; neighbors become supportive

text: But that was our welcoming to the neighborhood. And it was terrible and it certainly was frightening for me.
keypoint: Reflects on terrifying neighborhood welcome
